metadata.title: How To Use Data Science For Social Impact | by Jessie J. Smith | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: How To Use Data Science For Social Impact
metadata.description: Mathematicians, statisticians, computer scientists, social scientists, database administrators, data engineers, graphic designers, UI experts, journalists, storytellers, researchers, and business…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: CPI is directly correlated to per capita GDP

all_paragraphs: Data science is truly an interdisciplinary field.

Mathematicians, statisticians, computer scientists, social scientists, database administrators, data engineers, graphic designers, UI experts, journalists, storytellers, researchers, and business administrators are among many individuals involved in the process.
As machine learning and AI continue to advance, philosophers and ethicists will hopefully be included in the process as well.
Data science is powerful. If used correctly, it grants access to:

Utilizing Data comes in many forms. Netflix uses data science to recommend movies and tv shows to customers. Facebook uses data science to create targeted advertisements. Google uses data science to optimize search results. Amazon uses data science to have conversations with Alexa. Microsoft uses data science to create virtual realities.

Kaggle is using data science to predict poverty levels to identify where the highest need is for social welfare assistance. Code for Africa is using data science to create a tool that helps Kenyan citizens show up to the ballot box informed and ready to vote. DataKind is using data science to create more streamlined paths out of homelessness.
There’s a distinct difference between these two groups of data science users. The former utilize data for revenue. The latter utilize data for social impact.
How can we continue to leverage data science for social impact?
Defined by the Open Knowledge Foundation :
“Open data is data that can be freely used, re-used and redistributed by anyone.”

It’s clear that data science relies on data collection before anything else. There is no data cleaning, data analysis, or data utilization without data. The social impact projects from Kaggle, Code for Africa, and DataKind are fantastic, but they wouldn’t have been possible without access to data.

Kaggle couldn’t have begun predicting poverty if IDB didn’t give them their household income data. Code for Africa couldn’t have created any tools if the Independent Electoral & Boundaries Commission hadn’t released their location data on voter registration centers.
This is precisely why open data is the key to creating a social impact through data science. The more data that is available, the more opportunity there is to utilize it.
I’ll admit, there’s a bit of a dichotomy when it comes to open data. It’s a precarious balancing act between transparency and security.

I’ve already shared my thoughts about the need for data privacy. It’s important to address the potential misuses of open data before reaching a point of no-return. The Cambridge Analytica, Strava, and Equifax scandals clearly outlined why opening data can be bad.
This is why it must be done correctly.

It isn’t a good idea for Facebook to suddenly open up their databases for public access. It’s an equally bad idea for Google to share all of their private user information. To be clear, open data isn’t meant for all platforms.
The best use of open data is between governments and their people.

Buenos Aires uses their open data platform to inform the public about what the government is doing. They’ve made interesting reports with data visualizations to present important information to their citizens. They even created an interactive tool to help the public understand how the government allocates funds for the quarterly budget.

“The budget reflects what the State does with the resources it obtains from all citizens. It is important to communicate how these funds are used to stimulate participation, optimize controls and improve the level of public discussion.” -Buenos Aires Ciudad (translated from Spanish)
In Cali, Colombia the open data platform has allowed companies like DataPico to create tools that inform the public about crime distribution in their city.
I even used the open data platform myself when I was living in Cali to inform the public about where homicides are most likely to occur in their city.

Predictive policing is a good example of how data can be used to fight crime. While there are some important problems with predictive policing that will need to be addressed before this system is adopted by governments, the National University in Bogotá, Colombia is already working on a three year plan to utilize data to police the city more efficiently. The goal is to reduce crime.

When data becomes public, it is easier to share harsh realities with large audiences. Vox is a great example of a platform that provides information to the public through data visualization. In this story, Vox used data from entities in the USA to raise awareness about gun violence.

Remember that data science provides an “ability to understand the world in an objective way”. News outlets tend to present data analyses subjectively to the public. The beauty of open data is that raw numbers are objective. Open data provides the public access to the source of information, which allows everyone to draw their own conclusions.
This tool is a great example of how violence can be visualized objectively in the city of Cali. Data visualizations lead to public awareness.
When governments are forced to open their data, it becomes harder to hide corruption. Some examples of this:

Figure 2 outlines this process. When there is public awareness, a conversation begins between the government and the public. Conversations lead to collaboration. Collaboration allows governments to work with their citizens to create progress.
Progress builds trust between people and their government.

Trust is incredibly important for countries with a history of corruption. The Corruption Perception Index (CPI) of a country is an annually collected index that measures how corrupt citizens perceive their government to be. CPI is directly correlated to per capita GDP.

When citizens trust that their government is less corrupt, GDP rises. Just one unit of gained CPI has been proven to increase average per capita GDP by 1.7% annually. Perception of corruption is highly influential in developing economies.
TLDR: building trust between governments and citizens is very important. Open data helps to do this.
The major obstacle for open data is that it only works when everyone participates. I discuss this issue further in this article.

The hard reality of organizations like DataKind, Code for Africa, or Kaggle is that most social impact projects depend on volunteer work. Unfortunately, it’s hard to monetize projects that make a difference.

The good news is that the tools for change are right at our fingertips. Open data platforms are growing. Many coding classes are available for free online. Social impact seems well within reach. If you have access to a computer and to the internet, you are as qualified as anyone else to start working on projects that can make a difference in your community.
Data is our history. Data science is our future. All we have to do is build it.
This article was inspired by a coding workshop that I co-hosted with my brother in Cali, Colombia themed “How to Code and Achieve Social Impact.”
In the workshop, we discussed how open data platforms can help grow economies, fight corruption and crime, build trusting communities, and create a bridge between governments and their citizens.
In order to promote the open data platform in Cali, we’ve created and released Datos Profundos.

Datos Profundos is an open source repository that provides lectures and tutorials for individuals of any coding ability to understand data science. The tutorials use the open data platform of Cali to jumpstart the creation of social impact visuals and tools like those in Buenos Aires and Kenya.
The platform is accessible for both Spanish and English speakers.

Thanks for reading! Feeling motivated? My brother and I are starting a movement in Colombia to provide accessible coding education while simultaneously using tech for positive social impact. If you are interested in getting involved, please reach out!
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
PhD Student, Researching and Creating Technical Solutions to Ethical Problems in Society. Talking about AI Ethics at radicalai.org
